For those of you wondering where my next stop is, my answer is: I don't know, but I will embrace it. 

Goodbye for now.

My job has not been an easy one. I received an honest support and advice from leaders, my family and friends whom I thank deeply. We all have a shared memory. Our memories and experiences are all that we have and we should cherish them.

On this important day of my departure as the first woman President of the Federal Supreme Court of Ethiopia, I hope I have inspired women and young girls as they continue to assure me. I have served with utmost integrity and to the best of my knowledge and public interest. https://t.co/hjwBPk8p7h

I am deeply sorry by the untimely departure of the two young souls. My condolences to their family and friends. Let their soul Rest In Peace.

It is important for friends and family members to report when they observe unusual behavior so that early intervention is made. People with possible mental health issues could still be functional and that should not be misleading according to experts in the field.

The death of Federal First Instance Court Judge Tensay Belayneh, who committed suicide after killing his fiance yesterday is very sad. It was later reported that the judge exhibited unusual behaviors. https://t.co/h1mwhQZdaF

In view of encouraging corruption reporting in the bureaucracy, an ethics hotline will be launced soon.

To keep corrupt officials accountable, there needs to be evidence and it requires the participation of multiple stakeholders. The House of Peopleâ€™s Representatives and the Executive branch will collaboratively monitor corruption in the justice sector.
Regarding questions about the justice sector, the Prime Minister stated that there are judges and other justice sector officials who are working with integrity despite others who are overtly corrupt.

I attended the Prime Minister's question and answer session with the Parliament. H.E. the Prime Minister responded to wide-ranging questions raised by Members of the Parliament. https://t.co/wxdYYDUmUY

The success of any initiative including ND is dependent on the level of understanding and engagement on social media which it is a critical platform for African youth.
By using a systemic approach, we can prioritize issues for ND. It should be credible and inclusive to all interest groups including minority opinions. ND in a democracy is an on-going process.

Key takeaways:
ND is contextual and not a one-size fits all approach; it is a means and not an end; it can be an important new channel of communication and trust-building. It is complementary to existing institutions and mechanisms to ensure durable peace and democracy.
I attended an interesting all-women panel on National Dialogue (ND) at Tana Forum underway in beautiful Bahir Dar. https://t.co/86SEImmeQy

Concerns about unfair misrepresentation of judges and the judiciary, stressed that it has to stop to protect the integrity of a critical government organ. They added the importance of ensuring accountability of individual judges on a case by case basis per fact and evidence.

Even though the number of court users increased by 5,000, our judges have worked tirelessly to dispose these cases. I have big respect and admiration for them. The judges also expressed appreciation for the open and effective leadership of the court.

The Federal Supreme Court held an annual performance review and evaluation. During the past year, there were 25,000 cases brought to the court out of which 96% of cases were disposed of within one year. The one-stop service center was also implemented this year. https://t.co/07HSGfqoqz

Public defenders service is critical to avert punishment without guilt. Creating appropriate work space environment is crucial to provide quality service to court users.

The office currently has 73 defense attorneys out of which 34.3% are female. 11,947 clients accused of various crimes received defense attorney services at all levels of Federal Courts within the last 6 months.
We also visited the Public Defenders Office. Unprecedented reform in regards to the number of appointment of public defenders and improvement of benefit packages.

I held consultations with judges and administrative staff of the court to discuss areas of common interest and engagement. Very pleased with the progress made. Bravo to all!

I have seen the effective use of technology in providing efficient judicial services to court users. This bench oversees nearly 13,000 cases every year. I was pleased to hear that the main registrar and head judge of this bench are both female.

The court demonstrates key reform achievements including one-stop court service, case flow management, court-annexed mediation, random case assignments to judges, social worker support to custody litigation, and a day-care center.

We have worked on resource mobilization & establiahing partnerships. We have secured more than 5 million$ financial & technical support from multiple international organizations including @UNDPEthiopia @FetehActivityEt @USAIDEthiopia
@gatesfoundation @EUinEthiopia @OpenSociety 8

WeÂ invested in Technology including on a new user friendly website, SMS messaging to court users about the status of their case and a new case e-filing system. 

We have increased the number of women judges and appointed two women court leaders. 7

We haveÂ  revised the Judicial Code of Conduct emphasizing on Judicial ethical values & principles 

With our leadership Federal CourtsÂ  implemented a Case Flow Management System. 6
We have increased the salary of judges and improved the benefit package of judges including allocation of flats from the judges apartment. 5

Under the Federal Judicial Administration Council Establishment Proclamation (No. 684/2010), we made the composition of the #JudicialAdministrationCouncil to have more representation of judges, introduced mechanisms for ad hoc judges, &  increased the retirement age of judges. 4
We ensured the financial independence of courts by submission of a consolidated budget directly to the House of Peopleâ€™s Representatives. 3

We revised 2 major proclamations to ensure the independence of the judiciary. The Federal Courts Proclamation (No. 25/1996) introduced direct administration of non-judicial staff under the court. Previously, court staffs were under the Civil Service Commission. 2

* The African average score for Absence of Favoritism stands at 32.1 in 2017, due to a decline of -0.5 since 2014. 16 countries have seen an increase, mostly Guinea (+24.1), Gambia (+16.8) and Ethiopia (+11.8).4/4

*The Transparency & Accountability indicator to have declined the most since 2014. As a consequence, the African average score of 41.6 in 2017 is the lowest seen between 2008-2017. Only two countries, Ethiopia and Mali (both +7.2) have made progress since 2014. 3/4

* Representation of Women in the Judiciary is one of the indicators in the Gender sub-category. Seychelles (+75.0), Ethiopia (+50.0) and Swaziland (+50.0) are the most improved among the 11 countries which followed a positive trajectory since 2014. 2/4

Recommendations include issuing a detailed, clear and precise federal law; establishing an independent tribunal for land disputes; and ensure that dispute mechanisms recognized under the regional laws are presided 
 by qualified adjudicators/ experts.
